conceptual map
Sección
Meeting new people

Have you ever met new people during vacations? 

Meeting people is great, it helps you to expand your social circle. Meeting new people means to know another person’s experiences, their life story and what they’ve been through. Learning more about the people around you helps you to expand your horizons and understand the bigger picture of life as a whole. It gives you the opportunity to know about other places or to learn about many different things you didn't know. You can try new hobbies and, also, can hang out with your new friends in different places you haven't been before. 

Do you like to meet new people?

What could be some disadvantages of meeting new people?

Let's find out more about meeting new people!  

Survey
Text and Tasks
Are you ready to continue?

Objectives describe the expected outcomes of the learning and should define what the learners will be able to do when they have completed the learning tasks.
Type the learning objectives for this resource.

In this material, you will learn about relative clauses and the correct uses of relative pronouns. 

You will identify the difference between  restrictive and non-restrictive relative clauses. 

This activity is for students in B1 level.
Before we move on!

Prerequisite knowledge refers to the knowledge learners should already have in order to be able to effectively complete the learning. Examples of pre-knowledge can be:
  • Learners must have level 4 English
  • Learners must be able to assemble standard power tools
Describe the prerequisite knowledge learners should have to effectively complete this learning.

Provide instruction on how the cloze activity should be completed. Default text will be entered if there are no changes to this field.
1. Complete the sentences with the name of the subject according to the information.
University of Auckland
If this option is checked, submitted answers with different capitalization will be marked as incorrect.

1. Darla is the girl who is holding the lamp.

2. Bruce is the person who is eating all the cake. 

3. John is the guy whose belongings are being used by someone else. 

4. Gil is a dog whose owner is Tony .

5. Aaron is a boy that is pulling Ana 's hair.  

2. What are the parts of the sentences? 

Identify the subject, the verb and the object in the following sentences. 

Write subject, verb or object in the blank space depending on the part of the sentence to which the word is describing. 

1. He carries the dog. 

He is the subject .   

Carries is the verb .

The dog is the object .

2. He ate the whole cake. 

Cake is the object . 

He is the subject . 

Ate is the verb . 

3. The boy bothers the girl. 

Bothers is the verb . 

The girl is the object .

The boy is the subject .

If both "Strict Marking" and "Check Capitalization" are set, the only correct answer is "Elephant". If only "Strict Marking" is checked and "Check Capitalization" is not, "elephant" will also be accepted.

Cloze exercises are texts or sentences where students must fill in missing words. They are often used for the following purposes:

  1. To check knowledge of core course concepts (this could be a pre-check, formative exercise, or summative check).
  2. To check reading comprehension.
  3. To check vocabulary knowledge.
  4. To check word formation and/or grammatical competence.

If your goal is to test understanding of core concepts or reading comprehension

Write a summary of the concept or reading long enough to adequately test the target's knowledge, but short enough not to induce fatigue. Less than one typed page is probably adequate, but probably considerably less for young students or beginners.

Select words in the text thatare key to understanding the concepts. Thesewill probably be verbs, nouns, and key adverbs.Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test vocabulary knowledge

Write a text using the target vocabulary. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Highlight the target words in the text. Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test word formation/grammar:

Write a text using the target forms. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Remember that the goal is not vocabulary knowledge, so the core meanings of the stem words should be well known to the students.

Highlight the target words in the text. Provide alternatives with the same word stem, but different affixes. It is a good idea to get a colleague to test the test/exercise to make sure there are no surprises!

Learning about relative pronouns!
Relative clauses
University of Auckland

An activity can be defined as a task or set of tasks a learner must complete. Provide a clear statement of the task and consider any conditions that may help or hinder the learner in the performance of the task.
Describe the tasks the learners should complete.

Read the information to know about relative clauses, then answer the following activity. 

When we meet new people, when we visit a new place or when we learn something new about an object, we can use relative clauses to help us to express our ideas. We use relative clauses to describe or give extra information about something we have already mentioned.

What are relative clauses? 

A clause is a group of words containing a verb. Relative clauses are a way of giving more information about a person, thing, place, event, etc. We often use them to avoid repeating information. A relative clause is introduced by a relative pronoun.

What are relative pronouns?

A relative pronoun is a word that is used to refer to nouns mentioned previously, whether they are people, places, things, animals, or ideas. 

They are called relative pronouns because they always relate back to something or someone else.

A relative pronoun replaces the personal pronoun (I, you, he, they...)as the subject of the clause.

Relative pronoun Usage Example
who Refers to people.  This is the boy who broke the window. 
which Refers to animals and things. She gave me a cat which was very small. 
that Refers to people, animals and things. The activity that I am doing is interesting. 
whose Refers to possession.  She is the woman whose sister lives in Mexico City. 
when Refers to time.  He remembers the day when we met. 
where Refers to places. London is the city where my friend is living now. 

Relative pronouns can be used to join two sentences about the same person or thing.
Put it into practice!

Complete the sentences with the correct relative pronoun. In some sentences the first letter of the relative pronoun is already given.

If this option is checked, submitted answers with different capitalization will be marked as incorrect.

1. That bar over there is where I met Julie.

2. Julie is the person w ho  / t hat plays in a professional soccer team.

3. She plays for the soccer team w hich / t hat has more fans. 

4. I remember perfectly the day when I met her. 

5. My friends introduced her to me. They said, she is the student whose  abilities to play soccer are the best. 

6. Since that day we became good friends. Also she is the person w ho   tells the best jokes.

7. We hang out every weekend. This weekend we are going  to have breakfast in a new restaurant w hich was recommended by some friends. 

8. Next summer we are going camping, we are staying in a cabin whose walls are made of stone.

Do you know the types of relative clauses?
Restrictive relative clauses
University of Auckland

The Reading Activity will primarily be used to check a learner's comprehension of a given text. This can be done by asking the learner to reflect on the reading and respond to questions about the reading, or by having them complete some other possibly more physical task based on the reading.

Teachers should keep the following in mind when using this iDevice:

  1. Think about the number of different types of activity planned for your resource that will be visually signalled in the content. Avoid using too many different types or classification of activities otherwise learner may become confused. Usually three or four different types are more than adequate for a teaching resource.
  2. From a visual design perspective, avoid having two iDevices immediately following each other without any text in between. If this is required, rather collapse two questions or events into one iDevice.
  3. Think about activities where the perceived benefit of doing the activity outweighs the time and effort it will take to complete the activity.
Enter the details of the reading including reference details. The referencing style used will depend on the preference of your faculty or department.
What to read
Read the information about restrictive relative clauses, after that, answer the activities.
Describe the tasks related to the reading learners should undertake. This helps demonstrate relevance for learners.

There are two types of relative clauses in English, restrictive relative clauses  (they are also called defining relative clauses) and non-restrictive relative clauses (also called non-defining relative clauses). 

Restrictive relative clauses or Defining relative clauses 

As the name suggests, defining relative clauses give essential information to define or identify the person or thing we are talking about.  

A restrictive relative clause tells us which specific person or thing we are talking about in a larger group of people or things. If the restrictive relative clause is removed, the meaning of the sentence changes significantly. A restrictive relative clause is not separated from the rest of the sentence by commas or parentheses. 

Defining relative clauses are composed of a relative pronoun (sometimes can be omited), a verb, and other optional elements such as the subject or object of the verb. 

Examples: 

The woman who lives next door works in a bank. 
These are the classes that have been cancelled.

There was a one-year guarantee which* came with the TV.

* We can use which or that to talk about things, that is more common and a bit more informal.

Omitting the relative pronoun

Sometimes we can leave out the relative pronoun. For example, we can usually leave out who, which or that if it is followed by a subject.

The assistant [that] we met was really kind.
   (we = subject, can omit that)

We can't usually leave it out if it is followed by a verb.

The assistant that helped us was really kind.
   (helped = verb, can't omit that)
Use feedback to provide a summary of the points covered in the reading, or as a starting point for further analysis of the reading by posing a question or providing a statement to begin a debate.

Although more often used in formal testing situations MCQs can be used as a testing tool to stimulate thought and discussion on topics students may feel a little reticent in responding to. When designing a MCQ test consider the following:
  • What learning outcomes are the questions testing
  • What intellectual skills are being tested
  • What are the language skills of the audience
  • Gender and cultural issues
  • Avoid grammar language and question structures that might provide clues
Enter the question stem. The quest should be clear and unambiguous. Avoid negative premises as these can tend to be ambiguous.

When building an MCQ consider the following:
  • Use phrases that learners are familiar with and have encountered in their study
  • Keep responses concise
  • There should be some consistency between the stem and the responses
  • Provide enough options to challenge learners to think about their response
  • Try to make sure that correct responses are not more detailed than the distractors
  • Distractors should be incorrect but plausible
Enter the question stem. The quest should be clear and unambiguous. Avoid negative premises as these can tend to be ambiguous.

Give extra information!

Read the information. 

Non-restrictive relative clauses or Non-defining relative clauses

As the name suggests, non-defining relative clauses tell us more about someone or something, but the information in these clauses does not help us to define what we are talking about. Therefore, they give extra information. 

If the non-restrictive relative clauses were removed from the sentence, the sentence would still be grammatically correct and the meaning would not change, we would only have less details.

Non-defining relative clauses are composed of a relative pronoun, a verb, and optional elements such as the subject or object of the verb.  

Commas are always used to separate non-restrictive relative clauses from the rest of the sentence.

In non-defining relative clauses we can never use that.

Examples: 

Her grandmother, who is dead now, came from United States. 

I've met Susan, whose husband works in Aguascalientes.

His car, which is blue, is very expensive.

The name of the city, where she lives, is Puebla.

February, when Valentine's Day is celebrated, is the windiest month in some places.
Text and Tasks
Complete it!
Provide instruction on how the cloze activity should be completed. Default text will be entered if there are no changes to this field.
Complete the sentences with 'who', 'which', 'whose', 'when' or 'where'.
University of Auckland
If this option is checked, submitted answers with different capitalization will be marked as incorrect.

1. Last week he got a phone call from an old friend,   whose father died last week.

2. When I left they organized a party, which was a big surprise. 

3. His birthday, which was his 30th, turned out to be a nice day!

4. I sometimes exercise at the local park, where I can get fresh air.

5. In winter, when temperatures are lower, people prefer to stay at home.

6. Gorillas, which are from Africa, can be found in many zoos around the world.

7.  The singer, who I like the most, is giving a concert in my hometown next week.

8. The movie, which is based on a novel, won many awards.
If this option is set, each word will be marked as the learner types it rather than all the words being marked the end of the exercise.

Enter the text for the cloze activity in to the cloze field by either pasting text from another source or by typing text directly into the field.

To select words to hide, double click on the word to select it and click on the Hide/Show Word button below.

More than one possible answer can be defined enclosing them with pipes (|). I.e.: |dog|cat|bird|

If left unchecked a small number of spelling and capitalization errors will be accepted. If checked only an exact match in spelling and capitalization will be accepted.

For example: If the correct answer is Elephant then both elephant and Eliphant will be judged "close enough" by the algorithm as it only has one letter wrong, even if "Check Capitalization" is on.

If capitalization checking is off in the above example, the lowercase e will not be considered a mistake and eliphant will also be accepted.

If both "Strict Marking" and "Check Capitalization" are set, the only correct answer is "Elephant". If only "Strict Marking" is checked and "Check Capitalization" is not, "elephant" will also be accepted.

2. When I left they organized a party, which was a big surprise. 

3. His birthday, which was his 30th, turned out to be a nice day!

4. I sometimes exercise at the local park, where I can get fresh air.

5. In winter, when temperatures are lower, people prefer to stay at home.

6. Gorillas, which are from Africa, can be found in many zoos around the world.

7.  The singer, who I like the most, is giving a concert in my hometown next week.

8. The movie, which is based on a novel, won many awards.

Cloze exercises are texts or sentences where students must fill in missing words. They are often used for the following purposes:

  1. To check knowledge of core course concepts (this could be a pre-check, formative exercise, or summative check).
  2. To check reading comprehension.
  3. To check vocabulary knowledge.
  4. To check word formation and/or grammatical competence.

If your goal is to test understanding of core concepts or reading comprehension

Write a summary of the concept or reading long enough to adequately test the target's knowledge, but short enough not to induce fatigue. Less than one typed page is probably adequate, but probably considerably less for young students or beginners.

Select words in the text thatare key to understanding the concepts. Thesewill probably be verbs, nouns, and key adverbs.Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test vocabulary knowledge

Write a text using the target vocabulary. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Highlight the target words in the text. Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test word formation/grammar:

Write a text using the target forms. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Remember that the goal is not vocabulary knowledge, so the core meanings of the stem words should be well known to the students.

Highlight the target words in the text. Provide alternatives with the same word stem, but different affixes. It is a good idea to get a colleague to test the test/exercise to make sure there are no surprises!
Enter any feedback you wish to provide the learner with-in the feedback field. This field can be left blank.
Can you identify the type of sentence?
Are these relative clauses defining or non-defining?
Provide instruction on how the dropdown activity should be completed.
Select defining if the sentence has a defining relative clause or select non-defining if the sentence has a non-defining relative clause.

1. Mexico City, which is the capital of Mexico, is one of the largest cities in the world. non-defining

2. This is the dress my mother has made for me. defining

3. My grandfather, who is 85, goes swimming every day. non-defining

4. That's the dog that bit me. defining

5. Angelina Jolie, who has starred a lot of films, is a famous American actress. non-defining   

6. The town where I grew up is very small. defining

7. Anne, whose job involves travelling a lot, has been in 50 countries. non-defining

8. The hospital, where I work, is near my home. non-defining

9. This is the officer that arrested the thief. defining

10. She likes the bike that her father gave her. defining

Enter the text for the dropdown activity in to the dropdown field by either pasting text from another source or by typing text directly into the field.

To select words to choose, double click on the word to select it and click on the 'Hide/Show' button below.

Optional: Write other words to complete the dropdown activity.
Use | (vertical bar ) to separate words.
This field can be left blank.

1. Mexico City, which is the capital of Mexico, is one of the largest cities in the world. non-defining

2. This is the dress my mother has made for me. defining

3. My grandfather, who is 85, goes swimming every day. non-defining

4. That's the dog that bit me. defining

5. Angelina Jolie, who has starred a lot of films, is a famous American actress. non-defining   

6. The town where I grew up is very small. defining

7. Anne, whose job involves travelling a lot, has been in 50 countries. non-defining

8. The hospital, where I work, is near my home. non-defining

9. This is the officer that arrested the thief. defining

10. She likes the bike that her father gave her. defining
1. Mexico City, which is the capital of Mexico, is one of the largest cities in the world.
2. This is the dress my mother has made for me.
3. My grandfather, who is 85, goes swimming every day.
4. That's the dog that bit me.
5. Angelina Jolie, who has starred a lot of films, is a famous American actress.
6. The town where I grew up is very small.
7. Anne, whose job involves travelling a lot, has been in 50 countries.
8. The hospital, where I work, is near my home.
9. This is the officer that arrested the thief.
10. She likes the bike that her father gave her.

DropDown exercises are texts or sentences where students must select the correct words. They are often used for the following purposes:

  1. To check knowledge of core course concepts (this could be a pre-check, formative exercise, or summative check).
  2. To check reading comprehension.
  3. To check vocabulary knowledge.
  4. To check word formation and/or grammatical competence.

If your goal is to test understanding of core concepts or reading comprehension

Write a summary of the concept or reading long enough to adequately test the target's knowledge, but short enough not to induce fatigue. Less than one typed page is probably adequate, but probably considerably less for young students or beginners.

Choose words in the text thatare key to understanding the concepts. Thesewill probably be verbs, nouns, and key adverbs.Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test vocabulary knowledge
If your goal is to test word formation/grammar:

Write a text using the target forms. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Remember that the goal is not vocabulary knowledge, so the core meanings of the stem words should be well known to the students.

Highlight the target words in the text. Provide alternatives with the same word stem, but different affixes. It is a good idea to get a colleague to test the test/exercise to make sure there are no surprises!

What's wrong?
Provide instruction on how the cloze activity should be completed. Default text will be entered if there are no changes to this field.
Analize the sentences, find the mistake and correct it by adding the right word in the box (add only the corrected word). Do not use "that".
University of Auckland
If this option is checked, submitted answers with different capitalization will be marked as incorrect.

1. This is the chair who the carpenter repaired yesterday.    which

2. She is married to a man whose is richer than her.    who

3. She is the person when helped me with my homework.    who  

4. That is the swimming pool when I used to go swimming.    where

5. I am looking for a person which name is John.    whose

6. The writer, which I like the most, wrote a new novel.    who

7. That TV show, that was cancelled last week, is boring.      which  

8. Shakira, that is Colombian, sings very well.    who

For example: If the correct answer is Elephant then both elephant and Eliphant will be judged "close enough" by the algorithm as it only has one letter wrong, even if "Check Capitalization" is on.

1. This is the chair who the carpenter repaired yesterday.    which

2. She is married to a man whose is richer than her.    who

3. She is the person when helped me with my homework.    who

1. This is the chair who the carpenter repaired yesterday.
2. She is married to a man whose is richer than her.
3. She is the person when helped me with my homework.
4. That is the swimming pool when I used to go swimming.
5. I am looking for a person which name is John.
6. The writer, which I like the most, wrote a new novel.
7. That TV show, that was cancelled last week, is boring.
8. Shakira, that is Colombian, sings very well.

Cloze exercises are texts or sentences where students must fill in missing words. They are often used for the following purposes:

  1. To check knowledge of core course concepts (this could be a pre-check, formative exercise, or summative check).
  2. To check reading comprehension.
  3. To check vocabulary knowledge.
  4. To check word formation and/or grammatical competence.

If your goal is to test understanding of core concepts or reading comprehension

Write a summary of the concept or reading long enough to adequately test the target's knowledge, but short enough not to induce fatigue. Less than one typed page is probably adequate, but probably considerably less for young students or beginners.

Select words in the text thatare key to understanding the concepts. Thesewill probably be verbs, nouns, and key adverbs.Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test vocabulary knowledge

Write a text using the target vocabulary. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Highlight the target words in the text. Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test word formation/grammar:

Write a text using the target forms. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Remember that the goal is not vocabulary knowledge, so the core meanings of the stem words should be well known to the students.

Highlight the target words in the text. Provide alternatives with the same word stem, but different affixes. It is a good idea to get a colleague to test the test/exercise to make sure there are no surprises!

Now it's your turn!
Can you link the sentences?
Provide instruction on how the cloze activity should be completed. Default text will be entered if there are no changes to this field.
Join the sentences using relative pronouns, begin with the words given, add commas if necessary. Don't forget to add a period at the end of the sentence.
University of Auckland
If this option is checked, submitted answers with different capitalization will be marked as incorrect.

1. My school is very big. It is in Madrid. 

My school ,   which is in Madrid, is very big.

2. Scarlett Johansson is an actress. She plays Natasha Romanoff in the movie Iron Man 2. 

Scarlett Johansson is the actress who plays  Natasha Romanoff in the movie Iron Man 2.

3. I bought this cake yesterday. It tastes delicious.

The cake that I bought yesterday tastes delicious.

4. Marcos is a policeman. His father is a doctor.

Marcos, whose father is a doctor, is a policeman. 

5. I bought a phone last month. It doesn't work properly.

The phone that I bought last month doesn't work properly.

6. The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn was written by Mark Twain. I enjoyed it a lot.

The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn  , which I enjoyed a lot,   was written by Mark Twain.

7. That is the house. I was born in that house. 

That is the house where I was born.  

8. The Mayans built many stunning temples. The Mayans lived in Central America.

The Mayans, who lived in Central America, built many stunning temples.

9. That's the girl. Her brother is in my class. 

That's the girl whose brother is in my class.

10. In winter I'm going to visit Italy. My brother lives in Italy. 

In winter I'm going to visit Italy , where my brother lives .

If left unchecked a small number of spelling and capitalization errors will be accepted. If checked only an exact match in spelling and capitalization will be accepted.

For example: If the correct answer is Elephant then both elephant and Eliphant will be judged "close enough" by the algorithm as it only has one letter wrong, even if "Check Capitalization" is on.

If capitalization checking is off in the above example, the lowercase e will not be considered a mistake and eliphant will also be accepted.

If both "Strict Marking" and "Check Capitalization" are set, the only correct answer is "Elephant". If only "Strict Marking" is checked and "Check Capitalization" is not, "elephant" will also be accepted.

1. My school is very big. It is in Madrid. 

My school ,   which is in Madrid, is very big.

2. Scarlett Johansson is an actress. She plays Natasha Romanoff in the movie Iron Man 2. 

Scarlett Johansson is the actress who plays  Natasha Romanoff in the movie Iron Man 2.

3. I bought this cake yesterday. It tastes delicious.

The cake that I bought yesterday tastes delicious.

4. Marcos is a policeman. His father is a doctor.

Marcos, whose father is a doctor, is a policeman. 

5. I bought a phone last month. It doesn't work properly.

The phone that I bought last month doesn't work properly.

6. The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn was written by Mark Twain. I enjoyed it a lot.

The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn  , which I enjoyed a lot,   was written by Mark Twain.

7. That is the house. I was born in that house. 

That is the house where I was born.  

8. The Mayans built many stunning temples. The Mayans lived in Central America.

The Mayans, who lived in Central America, built many stunning temples.

9. That's the girl. Her brother is in my class. 

That's the girl whose brother is in my class.

10. In winter I'm going to visit Italy. My brother lives in Italy. 

In winter I'm going to visit Italy , where my brother lives .

Cloze exercises are texts or sentences where students must fill in missing words. They are often used for the following purposes:

  1. To check knowledge of core course concepts (this could be a pre-check, formative exercise, or summative check).
  2. To check reading comprehension.
  3. To check vocabulary knowledge.
  4. To check word formation and/or grammatical competence.

If your goal is to test understanding of core concepts or reading comprehension

Write a summary of the concept or reading long enough to adequately test the target's knowledge, but short enough not to induce fatigue. Less than one typed page is probably adequate, but probably considerably less for young students or beginners.

Select words in the text thatare key to understanding the concepts. Thesewill probably be verbs, nouns, and key adverbs.Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test vocabulary knowledge

Write a text using the target vocabulary. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Highlight the target words in the text. Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test word formation/grammar:

Write a text using the target forms. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Remember that the goal is not vocabulary knowledge, so the core meanings of the stem words should be well known to the students.

Enter any feedback you wish to provide the learner with-in the feedback field. This field can be left blank.

Put the ideas in order to complete the conclusion.

  • Now you know what relative clauses are.
  • You can use them whenever you want to describe something, someone
  • or whenever you want to tell extra information about something or someone.
  • Don't forget to use commas (or make a pause if you are speaking)
  • if you are giving extra information.
  • Also, never use that when you give extra information.
